Han, de 53 años, comenzó su carrera con: Han, 53, began her career with a group of poems in a South Korean magazine before making her prose debut in 1995 with a collection of short stories; she later began writing longer prose works, most notably The Vegetarian, one of her first books translated into English; the novel, which won the Man Booker International Prize in 2016, tells the story of a young womans attempt to live a more “plant-like” existence after suffering macabre nightmares about human cruelty; Han is the first South Korean author to win the literature prize and only the 18th woman among the 117 awards given since 1901; much of Han's work raises the question posed by a character in her 2019 novel Europa, whose protagonist is tormented by nightmares: “If you could live as you wished, what would you do with your life?”; although many of Hans protagonists are women, her prose is often narrated from a male perspective; “Before my wife became vegetarian, I had always thought of her as completely unremarkable in every way,” begins her novel The Vegetarian; “however, if there was no special appeal, there was also no particular disadvantage, so there was no reason for us not to get married”; originally written and published in Korean, The Vegetarian was translated by Deborah Smith, who was 28 at the time; Smith, who admits to having been “monolingual until 21,” chose Korean simply because of the lack of English-Korean translators; the Swedish Academy praised Hans work for its “unique awareness of the connections between the body and the soul, the living and the dead”; through her “poetic and experimental style,” the Academy said, Han “has become an innovator of contemporary prose”; Anna-Karin Palm, a member of the Nobel Literature Committee, said readers unfamiliar with Han's work should start with Human Acts, a 2014 novel that reflects on the 1980 Gwangju Uprising, when over 100 civilians were killed during the pro-democracy protests led by students in the South Korean city; Human Acts shows how “the living and the dead are always intertwined and how this kind of trauma remains with a population for generations,” Palm said at Thursday's announcement ceremony; but Hans “intense and lyrical” writing almost serves as a comfort in the face of this historical violence, Palm added; “her prose, very tender and precise, almost becomes a counterpoint to the brutal noise of power,” she said; before the announcement, Ellen Mattson, another member of the committee, explained how the jury selects each years laureate; “we start with a very long list of around 220 names,” Mattson explained; “then we have to navigate through that huge mass of names—and thats where we need the help of experts from different parts of the world”; in the end, the committee arrives at a list of “about 20 names,” which is then reduced to a shortlist of five authors; “thats where the real work begins,” Mattson explained; next, each committee member must “read everything those five authors have written” to start shaping a single winner.
